thread.title_full: Blue Jays' Jose Bautista comes through yet again in clutch situation [Photos]

title: Blue Jays' Jose Bautista comes through yet again in clutch situation [Photos]
text:
Just what has been Jose Bautista’s finest hour this post-season? 

Was it his three-run bomb in the crazy seventh inning of Game 5 of the Division Series, which capped the Blue Jays comeback against the Texas Rangers. 
If not then how about last night’s game where in the fourth he slammed a 428-foot solo homer to left and then in the eighth, trailing 3-1, he connected for a two-run shot to tie the game against Kansas City Royals reliever Ryan Madson? 
Two big-time shots by a big-time player in as big clutch situations as you can find. 
Bautista has brought himself a lot of heat in the post-season with his whining and complaining regarding the strike zone, his historic bat flip and his barking with the fans but man, talk about big-time performances and being pure clutch. 
Give the man his due. Reggie Jackson, move over. 
PRAYER TIME 
Every appearance that Roberto Osuna makes, the closer steps to the back of the mound, turns his back to the plate and says a prayer. Then after he gets the final out, he crosses himself, points skyward and says another quick prayer. 
“I just pray, I can’t tell you what I pray but I just pray and my mom does the same thing,” Osuna said of his ritual. “Then I give the best that I can like I promised just for them (his parents). I’ve been doing it since I was 16 years old.” 
And after the game? 
“I’m just giving thanks for letting me finish the game and letting me finish healthy,” Osuna said. 
Other than his parents, Osuna thinks of his grandmother. 
“She passed away when I was two years old but I remember her and all I do is for her,” he added. 
In what proved to be the final game of the season, Osuna came on after the rain delay and didn’t have his good stuff as he opened with a walk and then allowed the go-ahead run to score all the way from first on a single into the right-field corner. 
Other than Lorenzo Cain running, who would have scored on that play? 
The Royals hadn’t really flashed their wheels until that play. 
OY VEY 
In looking for redemption and avoiding the ignominy of becoming the first pitcher in post-season history to lose his first eight starts, David Price missed the mark. 
Instead, the veteran left-hander hit the middle of the Kansas City Royals bats and almost sent the Blue Jays packing. 
In looking to shed his loser tag and become a playoff mentsch, Price ended up like a post-season putz and it took a mighty two-run bomb by Bautista in the eighth to take him off the hook. 
Staring at a 3-1 loss and down to four outs, Bautista, who had hit a long solo shot in the fourth, crushed an offering from Madson to tie the game 3-3. 
Price’s sixth pitch of the game ended in the seats in left in the first inning and his 15th pitch of the game ended in the seats in right in the second inning. Two solo home runs, two body blows from which Price and the Jays almost didn’t recover. 
FIRST-INNING BLUES 
Sometimes the first inning tells you all you want to know. 
Last night looked like one of those times. 
In the top of the first, leadoff hitter Ben Revere yanked a Yolando Escobar offering down the first base line just inside the bag for a leadoff double. A good way to start. 
The positive vibes stopped right there, however, as Ventura retired the meat of the Jays order — Josh Donaldson, Bautista and Edwin Encarnacion — in order leaving Revere stuck at second. 
In the bottom of the frame, Ben Zobrist , batting second in the Royals lineup, belted a 1-1 pitch into the seats in left to power Kansas City into an early 1-0 lead. 
It set the tone for most of the game. Overall the Jays were 0-for-11 with runners in scoring position. 
THE HARD WAY 
In the fourth inning a mammoth solo shot by Bautista to left cut the Jays deficit to one run in the race to the seventh inning. 
Why the seventh. Well, if the Royals hold a lead after six they go to their bullpen and roll out Kelvin Herrera, Madson and Wade Davis to close it out. The trio usually comes through so it was imperative for the Jays to at least be in a tie by the end of the sixth. 
Their fifth inning opened on a promising note with consecutive walks to start the inning. Kevin Pillar took a strike, bunted foul and then flied out to centre as he failed to move the runners along. 
Had he done so it would have produced a run as Revere followed a deep fly to left on which Martin would have scored. 
It was up to Donaldson now and the Bringer of Rain tagged the first pitch, hit a bullet that third baseman Mike Moustakas snared inches off the ground after diving to his left. 
No runs, the Jays trailed 2-1. 
Taking no chances, Royals manager Ned Yost went to Herrera in the sixth with one out after an Encarnacion double. Herrera breezed through 1.2 innings before turning the ball over to Madson. 
MIDDLE MEN 
Middle infielders have been a pain in the butt for the Blue Jays this post-season. 
In the Division Series it was second baseman Rougned Odor of the Rangers who drove them crazy with his ability to get on base and his speed of foot. 
Picking it up where Odor left off and zooming on by him in the pain in the ass scale is Royals shortstop Alcides Escobar. Simply put he has been lights out at the plate and has been a table-setter extraordinaire. 
Against the Jays in the ALCS, Escobar batted .478 (11-for-23) while overall in the post-season he has raked at a .386 clip (17-for-44) with five RBIs and nine runs scored. 
“What he does, I think, is he really intensifies his focus,” manager Yost said in attempting to explain Escobar’s excellence in the post-season. 
“During the playoffs he just locks in. And when he’s focused, he’s as good as any player in the league at his position.” Sponsored Links
